statement.tex: %text Show that the differential equation \[ \qquad 2ye^{\frac{x}{y}}\cdot dx + \left(y-2xe^{\frac{x}{y}}\right)dy = 0\] is homogenous. Find the particular solution of this differential equation given that $x=0$ when $y=1$. %

\\ %text For \[ 2ye^{\frac{x}{y}}\cdot dx + \left(y-2xe^{\frac{x}{y}}\right)dy = 0\] to be a \underline{\text{homogenous}} differential equation, \underline\text{which} \underline{\text{of the following}} conditions must be true? %

\\ %text If \[ 2ye^{\frac{x}{y}}\cdot dx + \left(y-2xe^{\frac{x}{y}}\right)dy = 0 \implies \frac{dy}{dx} = F\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)\], then \underline{\text{which of the following}} is \[ F\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)\]? %
\\ %text If we let \[ z = \frac{y}{x}\], then \underline{\text{which}} of the following is true? %

\\ \begin{align} \frac{dx}{x} &= \frac{2e^\frac{1}{z}-z}{z^2}\cdot dz \\ \implies \int\frac{dx}{x} &= \underbrace{2\int\frac{e^\frac{1}{z}}{z^2}dz}_A - \underbrace{\int\frac{dz}{z}}_B \end{align} %text
Given this, \underline{\text{which of the following}} sets of statements is true? %

reason.tex:
%text A differential equation is homogenous if \[\quad\frac{dy}{dx} = N(x,y) \text{ where } N(x,y)\text{ is homogenous. }\]
And $N(x,y)$ is homogenous if \[ \qquad N(\lambda x, \lambda y) = N(x,y) \]
\underline{\text{But is \[ F\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)\] homogenous}}? \textbf{Yes}. Notice that if \[ F\left(\frac{y}{x}\right) = N\left(x,y\right) \], then \[ \qquad N\left(\lambda x,\lambda y\right) = F\left(\frac{\lambda y}{\lambda x}\right) = F\left(\frac{y}{x}\right) = N\left(x,y\right)\]
Hence, as \[F\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)\] is homogenous, therefore \[ \frac{dy}{dx} = F\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)\] is a homogenous differential equation. %

\begin{align} \text{If }z = \frac{y}{x},&\text{ then } y = z\cdot x \\ \implies \frac{dy}{dx} &= \underbrace{z + x\frac{dz}{dx}}_{\text{Chain Rule}} \\ \therefore \frac{dy}{dx} &= z + x\frac{dz}{dx} = \dfrac{2z\cdot e^{\frac{1}{z}}}{2e^{\frac{1}{z}} - z} \\ \implies x\frac{dz}{dx} &= \dfrac{2ze^{\frac{1}{z}} - z\cdot\left(2e^{\frac{1}{z}} - z\right)}{2e^\frac{1}{z} - z} = \dfrac{z^2}{2e^\frac{1}{z}-z} \\ \implies \dfrac{dx}{x} &= \dfrac{2e^\frac{1}{z} - z}{z^2}\cdot dz \end{align}
